description: First attested in the 1520s. Either from Latin accelerātus, perfect passive participle of accelerō (“I accelerate, hasten”), formed from ad + celerō (“I hasten”), which is from celer (“quick”) (see celerity), or back-formation from acceleration.

examples: ... a general knowledg of the definition of motion, and of the distinction of natural and violent, even and accelerate, and the like, sufficing.

verbs.description: accelerate (third-person singular simple present accelerates, present participle accelerating, simple past and past participle accelerated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to move faster; to quicken the motion of; to add to the speed of.
(transitive) To quicken the natural or ordinary progression or process of.
examples: to accelerate the growth of a plant, the increase of wealth, etc.

entries.meaning: (transitive, physics) To cause a change of velocity.
(transitive) To hasten, as the occurrence of an event.
(transitive, education) To enable a student to finish a course of study in less than normal time.
(intransitive) To become faster; to begin to move more quickly.
